title.narrative: Amélior° Adapt° et Résil CC sect agric

description.narrative: Projet de Renforcement des Capacités d'Adaptation et de Résilience aux Changements Climatiques dans le Secteur Agricole.
Améliorat° capacités Adaptat° CC dans 6 communes du Mali
independent political entity
The adaptive capacities of vulnerable rural populations to the additional risks posed by climate change on agricultural production and food security in Mali are enhanced

comment.narrative: Low
Indicative: 50%

So far the project reached over 300 collaborating producers (a third of them being women) that worked on demonstration and popularization plots. Demonstrated resilient agro-sylvo-pastoral technologies still stand on the use of seeds of adapted cereals and beans varieties as well as fodder plants, agro forestry and tree planting.
Sesame growing as income-generating activity was undertaken by 12 women from Mondoro rural Commune. Extension activities of approved tested technologies in Sandare Commune covered 38 ha out of which 6 ha of Niebe, 3 ha of groundnuts, 23 ha of sorghum and 6 ha of maize. Moreover, the number of demonstrated technologies has increased through (i) the introduction of four solar powered multi-functional platforms with a mill, a husker and a battery charger installed in four villages
across four municipalities, to strengthen production, (ii) installation of 4 market gardens (vegetable gardens) with 4 wells with tanks, 4 bore wells equipped with a solar pumping systems (overhead tank equipped with a solar batteries pomp) which launching will be done in the garden period, (iii) the erection of a micro dam in Massantola village and a regulator system in Gouantiesso/ M’Pessoba Commune will allow the irrigation of about 452 ha for the next agricultural season.

description.narrative: Existence of tools available to Malian actors (NGOs, associations, decisions makers, research institutes and technical services) to support climate change adaptation activities in agriculture and food security sectors

comment.narrative: Scarce and incomplete
Toolkits available for each of the 4 ago-ecological zone in Mali

The range of tools developed or adapted by the project range from climate proofing planning tools, sowing guidelines and calendars, technical agricultural forms, weather forecasting to other helping tools for decision making such as Social and Agro-Economical Analysis (AAES) and Technical data sheets to support decision making.

description.narrative: Percentage change in projected i) food production and ii) income generation in the pilot municipalities for available climate scenarios.

comment.narrative: Baseline will be evaluated at project inception in the context of project output 1.1.
Projected food production and income generation have increased in the pilot municipalities for available climate scenario.

The increase of both food production and income generated with the use of the resilient variety introduced by the project has been significant throughout the life of the project. During the 2014-2015 season, and despite am unfavorable rainfall that affected agriculture works in the project area, several demonstration plots still recorded satisfactory results. The Nyètaa Women Cooperative of Sandare -Diallara produced an average yield of 2,350 Kg/ha with the new maize variety against the community average yield of 450kg/ha; in Massantola, the agroforestry plots (eucalyptus-groundnuts) reached the yield of 1,392 kg/ha against a local yield of 400-450 kg/ha.
The “Jorobana” maize variety reached 2,292 kg/ha against the local variety production of 450 kg/ha.
In Cinzana, the sorghum CSM63E variety introduced by the project has a yield oscillating between 600 and 1320 kg/ha against a traditional production of 520 kg/ha. Similarly, the sorghum variety “Toroniou C1” registered a yield between 960 and 1,800 kg/ha against a traditional local production of 550 to 600kg/ha.
The fodder niebe plot of Cinzana Gare Women Association Benkadji II harvested 800 bundles of stalks for ox (animal) feeding (oxen and donkeys) provided by the project in 2013-2014. The Tiéba hybride maize varieties in M’Pessoba reached a yield oscillating between 2.680 and 3,600kg/ha against a local production of 850-900 kg/ha. The average yield of introduced sorghums, Séguifa, Tiandougou and CSM63E) is in the range of 1970 kg/ha against a traditional local production of 900-950kg/ha. Groubnut 47-10 pure cultivar registered an average yield of 1700 kg/ha as against a traditional local production of 600-650 kg/ha.

description.narrative: Capacities to prevent and manage the impacts of climate change on agricultural production and food security are improved
Number of municipalities having integrated adaptation considerations within their local development plans

comment.narrative: Very low/inexistent
High

Four communal plans for social and economic development (PDESCs) have integrated climate change issues – these are for the communes of Cinzana, Sandare, Massantola and M’Pessoba.
Unfortunately, the insecurity and political unrest in the north of Mali has impeded work in the communes of Mondoro and Taboye.

description.narrative: Existence of knowledge and tools within technical structures supporting rural development regarding needed adaptation measures in order to manage climate risks at the local level

comment.narrative: Low
High

Key stakeholders in project sites are already using the following tools developed or adapted by the project: Climate Proofing, Early Warning System, the CRIWAR, Geographical Information System, the sowing period guide with 80% of success in forecasting, the booklet of rainfall records, the technical data sheets of seasonal forecasts and the tool of Agro-Economical and Social Analysis (AAES). In addition, the project organized several awareness workshops targeting agriculture research and education institutions at regional, local and communal levels to raise awareness of climate change and include climate change modules in training curricula. (Sikasso Region: 10, Segou Region: 11, Koulikoro Region: 6, Kayes Region: 6)

comment.narrative: low

description.narrative: Budget/resources allocated to national and local strategies for adaptation

comment.narrative: Low/inexistent
Budget must be sufficient to implement articulated strategies and plans

The project supported the development of local funding strategies through the identification of decentralized financial structures operating in the communes of Sandare, Massantola, M’Pessoba and Cinzana and to establish a partnership to finance resilient agriculture that benefit eligible target populations.
The newly established Mali National Climate Funds (operational since March 2014) is dedicated to finance national and local strategies on adaptation and has been mobilized by the project for funding resilient agriculture.

description.narrative: Climate resilience of agricultural production systems and the most vulnerable agro-pastoral communities strengthened
Percentage of targeted farmers and local technical staff trained for collecting agro-meteorological data and using agro-meteorological information

comment.narrative:
More than 70% of the technical staffs (agents of agriculture, livestock breeding, water and forestry resources conservation, NGOs and educational institutions) involved in project activities in target communes trained on agro-meteorological data collection and the use of agro-meteorological information.
A total of 200 farmers (including 7 women and 8 technical agents) have been trained/re – trained on agro-meteorological data collection. One hundred and sixty (160) villages have been supplied with local rain gauges and rainfall data collection booklets.
The above data concern the communes of Sandare, Massantola, Cinzana and M’Pessoba.

description.narrative: Number of resilient agro-pastoral technologies or techniques demonstrated at the local level upon project closure

comment.narrative: Indicative: 15
With and equitable distribution of technologies or techniques benefiting men and women.

All demonstrated technologies are equitably profitable to both men and women in accordance with their respective needs. Close to 300 demonstration plots were implemented since the project inception, of these some 60 plots have been geared by women association groups. Seven (7) producers have been trained on the production and use of organic manure and have been issued with the relevant manure production equipment (wheelbarrows, pickaxes, shovels and rakes
Seven (7) women producers have been trained on rainfall quantities measuring technique, phytosanitary observations and plants phenological stages evaluation.
The exploitation of the 4 market gardens priority will be granted to women producers. The micro dams will equitably serve both men and women for the purposes of rice culture and market garden activities.

description.narrative: Percentage increase in production on parcels testing the resilient technologies or techniques

comment.narrative: To be determined based on the type of production

Yields and productivity has increased significantly in the project areas and parcels. As examples, the Sandare Diallara Women Nyètaa Cooperative has achieved an average yield of 2350Kg/ha for maize as against a local traditional production yield of 450kg/ha; corresponding to grow rate of 422%.
The Massantola eucalyptus-groundnut agroforestry plots reached a yield of1392 kg/ha as against a local traditional production yields of 400-450 kg/ha, amounting to a grow rate of 3227.53% « Jorobana » maize variety produced a yield of 2292 kg/ha as against a local traditional production yields of 450 kg/ha reaching a grow rate of 409.33%. In addition, in pure cultivation, the same corn variety recorded a yield fluctuating between 1430 kg to 3300kg/ha, in the same locality. In Cinzana, Sorghum CSM63E variety yields are oscillating between 600kg and 1320 kg/ha as against a local traditional production yields of 520 kg/h, i.e. a grow rate of 84.62%. Toroniou C1 Sorghum variety yields are oscillating between 960 et 1800 kg/ha as against local traditional production yields of 550 à 600kg/ha. The grow rate is 151%. The fodder Niebe plot of Cinzana Gare Benkadji II Women Association recorded 800 bundles of stalks for foxen (animal) feeding, bulls and donkeys supplied by the Project in 2013-2014.

description.narrative: Number of resilient alternative livelihood strategies demonstrated at the local level upon project closure

comment.narrative: Indicative: 15

The project promoted alternative livelihood strategies, the most important being the development of vegetable garden to support women resilience. To increase the number of beneficiaries and foster sustainability, process for involving microfinance institutions have been undertaken. 13 women associations and cooperatives (with 999 members) living in four communes received some equipment including plows, carts, and animals. In addition, the project supported multifunctional platforms using solar system energy. Recently, the project also introduced bovine fattening units, poultry farming as well as crafting activities for women (dyeing, pomade and soap manufacturing, and tailoring), as well as the production and sale of forest plants seedlings.
With and equitable distribution of strategies benefiting men and women.

All the income generating activities (AGR) equally profit both men and women. Rice culture in M’Pessoba and sesame in Mondoro are women-specific, in addition to market garden activities. Pure Niebe cultivation and fodder tree planting are carried out by women association and groups.

description.narrative: Best practices generated by the program capitalized on and disseminated at the national level
Number of vulnerable municipalities in which the lessons learned and best practices identified throughout the project have been disseminated

comment.narrative: Indicative:150

At this stage, promoting the uptake of good agricultural practices is in process throughout the six (6) communes of the Project. Dispositions are on the way for the organization of regional capitalization workshops, with the aim of diffusing in the other project target communes and the 166 vulnerable communes of Food Security Commissariat.

description.narrative: Number of national and international partner organizations to which lessons learned of the project have been directly presented

comment.narrative:
The following 12 organizations/stakeholders participate in the implementation of the Project: Direction Nationale de l’Agriculture, DNA (National Agriculture Direction), Agence de l’Environnement et du Développement Durable, AEDD (Environment and Sustainable Development Agency), Institut d’Economie Rurale, IER (Rural Economy Institute), Agence Mali Météo (Mali Meteorological Agence), Direction Nationale des Eaux et Forêts, DNEF (National Direction of Wild life and Game), Direction Nationale des Productions et Industries Animales, DNPIA (National Direction of Animal Production and Industries), NGO Mali Folck Center, LDCF/FAO Project, Office de la Haute Vallée du Niger, OHVN (Niger High Valley Authority), Centre National de Recherche Scientifique et Technologique CNRST (National Centre for Scientific and Technological Research ) and, as at that, they equally share the lessons learned by the Project.
Furthermore, some of the project results have been shared with UNDP’s climate change adaptation regional advisors at the international level.

Objective: Expand the coverage of Mali’s protected estate and strengthen the management effectiveness of the protected area system, focusing in the Southwest region and piloting new management models based on international PA categories.
1. Increase in land area of national territory managed as a Protected Area

comment.narrative:
In 2010 (baseline situation), Mali counted on the following with respect to its PA estate and key areas in the South West part of the country: (1a) The country’s PA estate covers 5,589,476 hectares of gazetted protected areas, covering 4.5% of Mali’s land area [*] (1b) Key habitats in the Bafing-Faleme region remain unprotected or were only recently gazetted. (1c) There is a ‘project’ to create the Bafing-Faleme Biosphere Reserve as the first Transboundary Biosphere Reserve in Mali composed of a mosaic of PAs of different categories and under varied management regimes, but only timid steps have been taken in this effectively creating the reserve. (1d) Within the central sub-complex of what will potentially be the Malian side of the ‘Bafing-Faleme Transboundary Biosphere Reserve’, there are at least 250,000 ha of ‘paper parks’Â? or areas that are gazetted by law but not managed. These include:
(i) Wongo National Park (53,599 ha)
(ii) Kouroufing National Park (55,770ha)
(iii) Chimpanzee Sanctuary (67,200 ha)
(iv) Falawa Game Hunting Preserves ZIC (73,940 ha) [indicator adjusted through a more detailed explanation] [NOTE on LOGFRAME 2014 - the text has been broken up in three numbered sub-indicators for the sake of readability; no change to content made] -------------- [* Note from 1a] Mali’s total territory covers 1.2 million sq km or, more precisely, 124,113,800 ha]

By project end, there will be major progress in expanding and operationalising Mali’s PA estate: (1a) The country’s PA estate reaches approximately 6,270,000 ha of gazetted PAs, covering at least 5% of Mali land area; This expansion will generally add ~700,000 ha of new protected areas to the estate, of which: (i) some 100,000 ha are expected to be created within the target zone of the project ; and (ii) some 600,000 ha would be from the establishment of the Tamesna Faunal Reserve for Gazelles in the Tin-Essako-Kidal Region, and for which the project is not responsible, but may function as a catalyst (e.g. through Output 1.2 on the PA Strategy [*]. (1b) The zoning of the Bafing-Faleme Biosphere Reserve has been completed and a master plan for managing the Reserve as mosaic of protected areas of different categories and under varied management regimes provides protection to key habitats in the Bafing-Faleme region (1c) The Bafing-Faleme Transboundary Biosphere Reserve has been created, i.e. the legal dossiers for submission to UNESCO have been cleared at the country’s level in close coordination with the Government of Guinea, and the documentation submitted to UNESCO’s Assembly for approval. (1d) Former 250,000 ha paper parks in the central sub-complex of the Bafing-Faleme Transboundary Biosphere, plus some 100,000 ha of new PAs within the mentioned reserve, are under improved management; this is evidenced by METT scores of 30% or above for the mentioned areas [indicator adjusted through a more detailed explanation] [NOTE on LOGFRAME 2014 - the text has been broken up in three numbered sub-indicators for the sake of readability; no change to content made] [* Note from 1a] Output 1.2 reads: National PA Strategy (under preparation) considers, among other relevant factors, the role of the new PA Authority, sustainable financing options, long-term PA expansion and consolidation, potential climate change impacts on the PA system, and defines immediate site action interventions for highly threatened PAs or endangered species dependent on a series of PAs.)

Making progress towards the target, but given the implementation time left and the complexity of the tasks, the target of PA expansion and strengthening is not likely to be achieved. After independent scrutiny by the MTR, the following was concluded on this indicator: 1a. Only A PA of 32,657 ha was created as a result of the project (Order of the 9 May 2011), namely the Hunting area of Faragama. Thus, only 33% of the target (of 100,000 ha new PAs within the project zone) was achieved. Given local conflict in the area, a (forest) management plan (FMP) has not been completed. In addition, activities in Community Reserves (totalling 167,699 ha) are only at the first steps of implementation. No community reserve (CR) was formally created with the assistance of the project. In fact, the legal process of CR creation has not even begun. A pre-condition to it would be the adoption of the Law on Wildlife and its Habitat, which is still in draft. It will only be submitted for approval in September 2015, with expected adoption by December 2015, if the process is not made contentious. Then the PA proclamation decrees would need to be submitted. At best, the proclamation of these community reserves would only be expected by June 2016, and therefore too late for the project to have an influence on it. 1b. The project has supported the management of 6 existing PA for a total 344,149 ha. These are: (i) Kouroufing NP with 55,770 ha; (ii) Wongo NP with 53,499 ha; (iii) Bafing Chimpanzees’ Sanctuary with 67,200 ha; (iv) Flawa Hunting Preserve 73,9440 ha; (v) Manda Wula Wildlife Reserve 39,050 ha; (vi) Mene and related Wildlife Reserve and its buffer and transition zone (BTZ) with 54,690 ha. PA strengthening activities have taken place but are still limited due to the lack of co-funding. The management plans for Neme Wula and Mande Wula have not yet been approved by a MEADD order. 1c. The cross-border biosphere reserve is not created. The MTR assessed that it won’t be by the end of the project. Overall, the MTR assessed that the MTR estimates tan the objective of this indicator is unlikely to be reached by the end and that if new PAs are still created, these will be “paper parks” with no management on the ground. Therefore the MTR suggested that the project should focus on the five CR with a total of 69,912 ha. The project’s replica is:
“Progress is being made to reach the target of creating new areas. The estimates are around 167,699 ha of new community areas to have created that have been delineated by boundary .. To achieve the objective, the project has to go to the other steps of the classification process (constitution of the classification committee, publication of the limits of the new areas, pending claims of riparian communities, analysis of claims, classification report and preparation of the act of filing, its adoption and publication in the Official Journal.) The creation of the new board of management of protected areas is underway”. Overall, performance for this indicator was deemed as MU by the MTR.

description.narrative: 2. Improved average METT scores for Mali_s protected areas

comment.narrative: Average METT scores of 17.5%
Average METT scores of 28%

Target achieved and surpassed.
The MTR has reviewed the METT applied to 6 sites and obtained an average rating of 33%. Details follow for points over a total possible of 102: (1) Kouroufing National Park = 40
(2) Mande Wula Reserve = 40
(3) Néma Wula Reserve = 40
(4) Wongo national Park = 42
(5) Chimpanzee’s Sanctuary = 57
(6) Yoroya Community Reserve = 29 The MTR further added that the rise of the average ratings was linked to the creation of the PA (or implementation of “on-paper” PA) or to their border demarcation. The MTR assessed progress as satisfactory for this indicator.

comment.narrative:

Gallery forests Forested savannahs
Gallery forests 0.5% Forested savannahs 2% per annum (including rotation agriculture)

Target achieved and surpassed.
The MTR has reviewed the METT applied to 6 sites and obtained an average rating of 33%. Details follow for points over a total possible of 102: (1) Kouroufing National Park = 40
(2) Mande Wula Reserve = 40
(3) Néma Wula Reserve = 40
(4) Wongo national Park = 42
(5) Chimpanzee’s Sanctuary = 57

description.narrative: Simplified indicator 1 - repeat

comment.narrative: Sub-indicators a, b and c as originally formulated by the project

Targets:
1a. 5.7 million ha (100,000 ha of new PAs) 1b. Good management of 350,000 ha of existing APs and 100 000 ha of new APs 1c. Creating cross-border of biosphere reserve

1a. An AP with a total area of ??32 657 ha was established by the project (by order of 9 May 2011). This is the ZIC of Faragama. Thus, only 33% of the target was achieved. PAG was not performed.
The activities in Community Reserves relate 167,699 ha, but are the first stage of implementation. No Community reserve was formally created.
Indeed, the legal process of establishing the Community Reserve has not begun. The prerequisite is the adoption of the bill on wildlife and its habitat. But the draft text will be submitted in September 2015 at best hoped for adoption by December 2015. Then the legal texts on the 12 RC should be submitted. 1b. The project has supported the management of six existing APs from a total of 344 149 ha: National Park Kouroufing (55,770 ha) National Park Wongo (53 499 ha), Sanctuary of the chimpanzees Bafing (67 200 ha), ZIC Flawa of (73 940 ha), Mande Wula Wildlife Reserve (39,050 ha), wildlife reserves of Nema Wula and ZTT (54 690 ha). Field activities exist but are still limited (particularly due to the virtual absence of co-financing). Management Plans and reserve management Mande Wula and Nema Wula have not yet been officially approved. They have been technically validated in the workshop. 1c. Border Biosphere Reserve is not created.

Approximately 5,704,696 ha of gazetted PAs (over 4.6% of Mali)

Indicator should be dropped according to the MTR, which says “This indicator is not clear or it is redundant”. As noted in previous PIR iterations, the Malian territory is very vast. Accounting for PA expansion in terms of percentages can therefore be meaningless. Accounting for it in absolute terms is already being done in Indicator #1. Hence, nothing to report. description.narrative: 5. Capacity Assessment Scorecard

comment.narrative: [see below]
[see below]

[broken down by sub-indicators below / herein narrative assessment based on the MTR] The CDS tool permits to measure the increase of the capacities of actors involved in PA management. It was applied in 2009 during project formulation. It considers the systemic level (PA system), the institutional level (involved entities) and the individual level. During the MTR (Mid-Term Review) field mission, the CDS was applied in order to measure the evolution in terms of capacity development since the project started. The results:
Systemic 12/30 (42%)
Institutional 13/45 (34%)
Individual 9/21 (44%)
(Average 35%) The material, technical and human capacities granted for PA management are limited and have lightly improved during the project. It can surely be explained by the major crisis that Mali had to face: institutions have largely been weakened and the State suppressed funds for the PA system (in particular the majority of the project co-funding). However Mali could have benefited from international skills, but the project team did not enlist them. For instance, regarding the occupation of the PA, capitalization from other West African country could have helped the project team to anticipate and remedy conflicts through mediation. A study trip was realized in Senegal but was not enough to find solutions. An experience feedback in the Ivory Coast case, like in the CORENA project (which realized a complete study on occupation of PA), could bring solutions on the PA occupation matter. On the field, the presence network of forestry agents in Bafing was lightly rehabilitated, but not in a sufficient way regarding needs. Agents also need motivation (and formation to realize their mission. Project has effectively realized formation but 60% of the formed agents have been transferred to other situations. This cannot allow capitalizing on achievements and continuing them.
If material needs are necessary, they are not enough. The field surveys have brought to light that surveillance is not efficient even if the project brought 18 motorbikes to ease surveillance. No infraction was signaled though satellite imagery reveals an upsurge of infractions (illegal exploitation, forest clearing, etc.) Financial perpetuation of the NSPA is a major issue and the project team does not have the skills to realized fund seeking (which should be the role devoted to the Principal Technical Advisor). The financing study of PA does not meet a sufficient quality. It is recommended to elaborate a true Business Plan and a pragmatic financial perpetuation strategy by the end of the project. The MTR assesses that the sensitization level of executive officers, technicians, local and regional decision-takers, communities and other local stakeholders is not sufficient enough for an efficient PA management system in Mali. It is indispensable to forecast an important program to reinforce the capacities and also that the next project (ERSAP II) accepts the idea of benefiting from international expertise to reinforce its own capacities.

description.narrative: 6. Financial Sustainability Scorecard

comment.narrative: [see below]
[see below]

[broken down by sub-indicators below / herein narrative assessment based on the MTR] Quoting from the MTR:
FSC allows to measure financial sustainability of the PA management system. It was applied in 2009 during project formulation (at the same time as METT rating) and revised in 2013. The project team met important difficulties to obtain financial data; it tends to overestimate the obtained scores. The total score of the MTR is 27/197 (14%).
Component 1: 14/75 (18%)
Component 2: 4/61 (7%)
Component 3: 9/57 (16%)
Total: 27/197 (14%)
The evaluation reveals a global improvement of the FSC but still beneath the fixed objectives. The law on fauna and its habitat is not yet adopted limiting component 1’s score. Regarding the bad quality of financial strategy (product 1.5) not attached to business plan. The MTR proposes to upgrade the strategy before attaining a quality document by the end of the project.

description.narrative: 6a) Component 1 - Legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks

comment.narrative: A min. of 20% at least by EOP.

Target almost achieved. Component 1: 14/75 (18%) With respect to this component / part of the Scorecard, the project is proud to report progress, beyond the actual and percentage points: The draft texts of the creation of the new body of management of protected areas are validated. They were submitted to the commission for institutional development. Waiting for results from the commission
The draft wildlife management and habitat legal texts are technically validated. Regional and national consultations were held. The final version of the Wildlife Management Code project and its habitats will be submitted to the meeting of Secretaries General before its adoption by the National Assembly by the end of the year.

Targets surpassed for the six METT sites assessed in July 2015. The MTR has validated the METT application and reports the following: See comments of indicator 2 (redundancy)
The following results have been granted by the MTR (Mid-Term Report):
(1) Kouroufing NP = 40
(2) MW Reserve = 40
(3) NW Reserve = 40
(4) Wongo NP = 42
(5) Chimps’ Sanctuary = 57
(6) Yoroya Community Reserve = 29
The Wongo complex presents important progresses. These PA have gone from a theoretical (“on-paper”) status to an implementation status. Thus, scores have improved significantly.
The Galé-Limakollé legally exists (even disposes of a FMP even though it is not yet validated) but is facing to a major occupation issue (by populations).
Moreover, community reserves only are at the very first step of their creation; the legal process absolutely must result by the end of the project. The MTR rates this indicator S for Satisfactory, regarding the progresses attained since the project started.

description.narrative: 8. Basic PA management tools in place: Management plan, PA Manager, staff and resources available

comment.narrative:
8a) No active Management Plan for any of the pilot PAs
8b) No permanent staff or management for any of pilot PAs

8a) Management plans available electronically 8b) Manager and staff in place and trained [NOTE ON LOGFRAME 2014: there are no quantifiable target(s) for these sub-indicators, which is not useful. We will propose something based on the sub-complexes of PAs after the MTR and upon their advice.]

Target considered achieved as per the MTR. The MTR reports: 8a. The 4 FMP of the Wongo complex have been realized: Kouroufing NP, Wongo NP, Hunting Area of Flawa, Chimpanzee’s Sanctuary. FMP have been realized but no yet validated. FMP for Faragama Hunting Area has not been realized. 8b. Staff has been recruited and is in place on the Wongo complex. Even though they don’t reach a sufficient number, it’s a significant progress regarding the initial situation (before the project). They have been equipped with motorbikes. Infrastructures have been restored, a forest post in Niarakira has been restored and one is being constructed in Kouroukoto. In conclusion, the MTR evaluates this indicator to be satisfying according to the progresses made.

description.narrative: 9. Alternative Livelihoods generate increased revenues for local populations

comment.narrative: No ecotourism economic activities in region
3 new community based ecotourism operations generating revenue and jobs

Target not achieved -- No ecotourism activity. A directory of cultural sites is outstanding preparation. If people were well involved in the project, the majority of respondents say villagers see protected areas as constraints and not as an opportunity (especially income generation). Alternative activities initiated by the project will have to be intensified in order to have a significant impact on local populations of protected areas. Moreover, given the country's instability (which strongly impacts tourism) and very limited resources (lack of co-financing anticipated), investment in ecotourism home can be very risky. The MTR reports:
Even though populations have been involved in the project, the majority of enquired villagers see PA as constraints and not as an opportunity. Alternative activities initiated by the project will have to be intensified to have a significant impact on the populations living near the PA. The project team could not provide any socio-economic study quantifying generated income of the project’s beneficiaries. Moreover, given the country’s instability (strongly impacting tourism) and the limited resources (absence of expected co-funding), the MTR warns on the risk inherent in investing in eco-touristic welcoming.
Project team has been asked to lead a reflection on it and reconsider this objective if needed. In conclusion, the MTR assesses that the objective will not be reached by the end of December 2015. It recommends to revise the initial objective (of creating 3 sites of ecotourism) to focus on one pilot (even 0 according to the results of the reflection led by the project team) and reinforce alternative activities with populations living near PA (in particular, by developing partnerships with the projects of the given zone).

description.narrative: Wider-landscape conservation in buffer and transition zones of biosphere reserves of SW Mali will reduce key pressures on core PAs and biodiversity
10. Quantifiable status of vegetative cover in the Bafing-FalÃ©mÃ© Biosphere buffer and transition zones (BTZ)

comment.narrative:
10a) No accurate land use map of PA and BTZ available
10b) No marked zoning
10c) No clear legal status for BTZ of Biosphere Reserves

10a) Arial photography and [*] satellite images treated in GIS [*NOTE 2014: a better formulation for this sub-indicator should be â€œand/orâ€?.]
10b) BTZs clearly marked on ground direct observation 10c) Legal status clarified and understood by 50% of village leaders in surrounding villages (questionnaires)

Target considered achieved. See comment from MTR: The project obtained and analyzed satellite images of 2010 and 2014 of the Bafing-Faleme area. Ecological monitoring, implemented by the project, has been able to highlight very strong degradations of the vegetal cover in the area throughout the four years (see comments on indicator 3)
Main pressures on PA and their biodiversity have not been reduced. Images of 2012 and 2015 (soon available for the project team) will refine the analysis. PCAE (Plans Communaux d’Action Environnementale) were realized 11 communes (3 in Kita’s circle, 3 in Bafoulabé’s circle and 5 in Kéniéba’s circle). In order to implement these PCAE, Communal Councils must be escorted by the project to obtain funds, develop partnerships and ensure their implementation. Identification plates have been posed within migration corridors of the Bafing-Faleme area. However, sensitization action (what’s a BTZ for?) and formation (on bushfires particularly) haven’t yet reached sustainable results. Populations’’ escorting must be intensified. The fauna and its habitat management Code includes a clarification of BTZ in Mali. Nevertheless, this law has not been yet approved (see Table 4). BTZ of the Bafing-Faleme areas are thus not created. The evaluation recommends to implement a proactive lobbying to accelerate this legal process. Field surveys showed that populations are confused with the PA classification and to get the differences between each one of them. Villagers don’t acknowledge limits and functions of BTZ. The mid-term evaluation team insists again on the importance of conducting sensitization action: preservation cannot be made without the populations!
Thus, the team rates this indicator MS and recommends (1) to realize an efficient lobbying for the fauna and its habitat law and its decrees, (2) to realize a real escort of populations (including sensitization), (3) reduce realization targets of the BTZ of the project (these actions will be able to be continued in a future project, still it is important that ERSAP focuses and achieves priority activities).

description.narrative: 11. Stabilization of the number and distribution of threatened, indicator or migratory wildlife species in critical habitats to be defined at the project’s inception phase [indicator adjusted through an added explanation on critical habitats]

comment.narrative:
Derby eland 0.01 individuals / km2 (estimate)
Roan antelope 0.47 inds/km2
Buffalo 0.12 inds/km2
Hippopotamus - unknown
Lions - unknown
Chimpanzee ‘ between 1800 and 3500 individuals in Mali
General target: An average increase of 10% in population density at project end (surveys) [Means of verification: Species distribution map]

Not possible to adequately inform this indicator. Else, the MTR reports the following: Aiming to measure the biodiversity preservation within the BTZ of the southwest of Mali, 6 indicators were suggested in the PRODOC: (1) Derby Elk, (2) Roan Antelope, (3) Buffalo, (4) Hippo, (5) Lion, (6) Chimps.
This indicator is too complex regarding the reality of the project and references figures are not all specified or are unreliable. This particular issue should have been raised during launching workshop.
Two inventories were realized within the Wongo Complex (2013 and 2014) and an inventory was realized within the Galé-Limakollé. A German research team is in the Kouroufing NP. They observed 1 Leopard, 14 chimps, baboons, Caracals, Damans, Genettes, Mongooses, Panthers and Warthogs on the first recordings watched. The evaluation team recommends to establish a partnership protocol with the research and to offer assistance to write down the TOR (Terms Of Reference) of an internship with the objective of counting the population of a flagship species within the Wongo complex. This internship should begin in September (starting of the academic term - Master degree internship).

description.narrative: 1.Nombre de femmes et d'hommes âgés de 15 à 49 ans conseillés et dépistés au VIH et qui ont reçu leurs résultats 2.Nombre de femmes enceintes VIH+ ayant bénéficié du traitement Antirétroviral (ARV) pour réduire la transmission de la maman à l'enfant 3.Nombre de femmes enceintes qui connaissent leurs statuts sérologiques 4.Nombre d'enfants nés de mères séropositives ayant bénéficié d’un dépistage dans les 18 mois suivant la naissance par technique de chaîne de polymérisation à réaction (PCR) 5.Nombre et pourcentage de poches de sang testées au VIH selon le protocole national de qualité 6.Nombre d'adultes et d'enfants atteints d’une infection avancée au VIH et qui reçoivent un Traitement ARV selon le protocole national 7.Nombre d'adultes et d'enfants vivants avec le VIH qui reçoivent la prophylaxie au cotrimoxazole selon le protocole national 8.Nombre de patients traités pour coïnfection Tuberculose (TB/VIH) dans les sites de prise en charge pendant la période de rapportage 9.Nombre d'adultes et d'enfants sous traitement ARV dont leur statut tuberculose a été évaluée et enregistrée au cours de leur dernière visite 10.Nombre de sites de traitement qui n'ont pas connu de rupture de stock les 3 derniers mois

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - policy, planning and administration

1. Nombre d’infrastructures réhabilitées, équipées et fonctionnelles (Cible : 120 infrastructures) 2. Nombre d’équipements informatiques et bureautiques additionnels mis à la disposition des agents de l’Etat (Cible : 200 kit soit 70% des besoins recensés) 3. Nombre de matériel bureautique et stock de papier livrés aux différentes structures de l’Etat (200 kit soit 70% des besoins recensés) 4. Nombre de mallettes de textes usuels mis à la disposition des services d’ordre et de justice (200 mallettes) 5. Nombre d’initiatives entreprises pour améliorer les relations de travail et restaurer la confiance entre les usagers et l’administration (50 QIP financés par le PNUD avec une forte implication de l’administration)

comment.narrative: 1. Zéro (en 2013) infrastructure et installation en bon état (commissariat de police, prisons et Palais de justice et résidence professionnelle) en état de fonctionnement 2. Cinq pour cent (en 2013) des équipements informatiques et de bureau en état de fonctionnement 3. Cinq pour cent (en 2013) du matériel bureautique et stock de papier disponible 4. Zéro (2013) textes du droit positif applicable par les services d’ordre et de justice disponibles 5. Relation de travail et de confiance entre l’administration et les populations détériorées

1. Vingt-deux (22) infrastructures réhabilitées et fonctionnelles (Brigade des stupéfiants de Bamako: 1, Tribunaux et logements d’astreinte des juges de Diré (Tombouctou) : 2, de Goundam (Tombouctou): 2, de Gourma Rharous (Tombouctou): 2, de Youwarou (Mopti) : 2, de Douentza (Mopti) : 2, le Tribunal de Mopti: 1, la Cour d’appel de Sévaré (Mopti): 2, de Téninkou : 2, Ansongo: 2, Ménaka: 2 et Bourem: 2) 2. Deux cent cinquante (250) divers équipements informatiques et mobiliers de bureau livrés aux préfectures, sous préfectures, mairies et prisons des régions de Gao (Gao, Ansongo, Bourem, Ménaka); les prison, préfecture et sous préfecture de Kidal; la prison, le commissariat de Mopti (Youwarou, Teninkou, Douentza, Mopti) 3. Cent (100) matériels de bureau et stock de papier livrés aux 5 maisons d’arrêt de Tombouctou, Diré, Goundam, Niafounké, Gourma rharous, au Tribunal de Grande instance de Tombouctou et la Direction régionale de l’administration pénitentiaire de Tombouctou 4. Deux cent (200) mallettes de textes usuels mis à la disposition des services d’ordre et de justice, notamment les maisons d’arrêt de Gao, Mopti et Douentza 5. Quinze (15) initiatives prises pour améliorer les relations de travail et restaurer la confiance entre les usagers et l’administration

1. 14 infrastructures réhabilitées et fonctionnelles dont la brigade des stupéfiants de Bamako:1, Tribunaux et logements d’astreinte des juges de Diré (Tombouctou) : 2, de Goundam (Tombouctou): 2, de Gourma Rharous (Tombouctou): 2, de Youwarou (Mopti) : 2, de Douentza (Mopti) : 2, le Tribunal de Mopti: 1 et la Cour d’appel de Sévaré (Mopti): 2 2.120 divers équipements informatiques et mobiliers de bureau livrés aux prisons de Douentza et de Mopti 3. 200 matériels de bureau et stock de papier livrés aux 5 maisons d’arrêt de Tombouctou, Diré, Goundam, Niafounké, Gourma rharous, au Tribunal de Grande instance de Tombouctou et la Direction régionale de l’administration pénitentiaire de Tombouctou 4. 0 5. 04 initiatives (Transformation des produits maraîchers, la Savonnerie, l'Embouche bovine et la Production de pain locale) prises pour améliorer les relations de travail et restaurer la confiance entre les usagers et l’administration (Tombouctou)

1. Soixante six (66) infrastructures réhabilitées et fonctionnelles (9 Tribunaux/bureaux: Ansongo: 1; Ménaka: 1; Bourem: 1; Mopti: 1; Djenne : 1; Bankass 1; Bandiagara: 1; Koro : 1; Kidal: 1). 10 Résidences des Juges: Ansongo: 1; Ménaka: 1; Bourem: 1; Mopti: 3 ; Djenne : 1; Bankass 1; Bandiagara: 1; Koro : 1). 17 Centres d'accès au droit et à la justice dans les régions de Gao (3), Mopti (9) et Tombouctou (5). 10 Résidences et bureaux de gouverneurs et conseillers dans les régions de Gao (1), Mopti (4) et Tombouctou (5). 6 mairies dans les régions de Gao (2), Mopti (1) et Tombouctou (3). 3 conseils de cercle dans les régions de Gao (1) et Tombouctou (2); 5 maisons d'arrêt dans les régions de Gao (3), de Mopti (1) et Tombouctou (1). 3 camps de garde dans la région de Mopti; 1 gendarmerie dans la région de Mopti; 2 commissariats de police dans les régions de Gao (1) et de Mopti (1). 2. Deux cent (200) divers équipements informatiques et mobiliers de bureau livrés aux tribunaux 3. Non défini 4. Non défini 5. Cinq (5) initiatives prises pour améliorer les relations de travail et restaurer la confiance entre les usagers et l’administration

Quarante quatre (44) infrastructures réhabilitées et fonctionnelles dont : 5 Tribunaux/bureaux: Mopti: 1; Djenne : 1; Bankass 1; Bandiagara: 1; Koro : 1. 6 Résidences des Juges: Mopti: 2; Djenne : 1; Bankass 1; Bandiagara: 1; Koro:1.13 Centres d'accès au droit et à la justice dans les régions de Mopti (8) et Tombouctou (5). 9 Résidences et bureaux de gouverneurs et conseillers dans les régions de Mopti (4) et Tombouctou (5). 4 mairies dans les régions de Mopti (1) et Tombouctou (3). 2 conseils de cercle dans les régions de Tombouctou (2); 1 maison d'arrêt dans la région de Tombouctou (1). 3 camps de garde dans la région de Mopti; 1 gendarmerie dans la région de Mopti; 0 commissariats de police 2. comment.narrative: 1. Zéro (0) 2. Cinq pour cent (5%) 4. 1 Formateur, 5 personnel d'appui, 0 policiers formés
